thatâ€™s assigned to the political branches and the president,â€ said August Flentje, a longtime DOJ lawyer who at times hesitated when pressed by the judges to explain if the presidentâ€™s power over immigration is as unfettered as the administration makes it out to be.Flentje insisted that U.S. District Judge James Robart, in blocking the travel ban last month, â€œdisturbedâ€ the balance with the other branches of government â€• a disruption that caused â€œirreparable harmâ€ to the Trump administrationâ€™s ability to protect the country.But U.S. Circuit Judge Michelle Friedland seemed skeptical that courts should simply stay out of these kinds of disputes, no matter how sensitive they might seem at first blush.â€œAre you arguing that the presidentâ€™s decision in that regard is unreviewable?â€ the judge asked Flentje, who later conceded that â€œthere are obviously constitutional limitationsâ€ to what the president may do with his authority.Trump and his administration have repeatedly come under scrutiny over whether his executive order amounts to a so-called Muslim ban, and statements he and his associates have made during the campaign or since loomed large over the hearing.At one point, Friedland wondered whether the court should consider those statements as proof that the travel ban was instituted with â€œbad faith,â€ while U.S. Circuit Judge Richard Clifton suggested that comments made by the likes of Rudy Giuliani about how the order came to be could serve as evidence of discriminatory motive.â€œDo you deny that those statements were made?â€ Clifton asked of the DOJ lawyer, who elsewhere in the proceedings said the court should simply look to the â€œfour cornersâ€ of Trumpâ€™s executive order â€• and not to things beyond what it says. Washington Solicitor General Noah Purcellâ€™s burden was different than that of the DOJ: to show that Trumpâ€™s order causes his state and Minnesota â€œirreparable harmâ€ â€• and that reinstating the ban would simply bring more disruption to state universities, businesses and residents who depend on the states for essential services.But on the broader point about the orderâ€™s legality, Purcell said the weight of the statesâ€™ allegations, even at this early stage in the case, indicated that the travel ban is likely unconstitutional. â€œHere weâ€™ve alleged very plausibly and with great detail that this was done to favor one religious group over another,â€ Purcell said. Among other violations, the states have asserted that Trumpâ€™s travel restrictions violate the Constitutionâ€™s guarantees of religious freedom and equal protection of the laws.The 9th Circuit, which is expected to rule later this week, probably wonâ€™t touch the merits of those claims. Instead, the court is likely to issue a procedural ruling indicating whether the lower courtâ€™s temporary order should be lifted or upheld â€• which would be followed by more evidence-gathering, more hearings, and a more substantive ruling by Robart, the district judge.However that plays out, the controversy over the travel ban is likely to land before the Supreme Court, which remains one member short. Maybe by then, Trumpâ€™s nominee to the high court, Neil Gorsuch, will be seated to consider the case.Because of the high-profile nature of the dispute, the 9th Circuit made audio of the hearing available live on YouTube, and it was separately carried by CNN. By the time it ended, the YouTube feed had more than 135,000 listeners.

headline: Why Lin-Manuel Miranda Says We Shouldn't Judge Hollywood Diversity By The Oscars
short descr: "Thereâ€™s no shortage of Latino talent both in front of and behind the camera."
image_caption(s): Leigh Blickley - Senior Entertainment Reporter, HuffPost
article: Lin-Manuel Miranda doesnâ€™t think the Academy Awards should be a barometer for Hollywood diversity.The â€œHamiltonâ€ creator, whose musical made a point to bring onboard a diverse cast to tell the story of a white figure, spoke to The Huffington Post recently about Latino representation in Hollywood.When asked about why he thought the Oscars have improved when it comes recognizing black actors but not Latino actors, Miranda said he believes itâ€™s perilous to â€œmeasure the health of an industryâ€™s regard to diversityâ€ through its awards.â€œI think itâ€™s a great way to get a lot of articles, but like we had a really diverse season on Broadway last season because we had the amazing good fortune of having â€˜Color Purpleâ€™ and â€˜Shuffle Alongâ€™ and â€˜Hamilton,â€™ and it may not be as diverse this season and that has everything to do with when the theater is open and what shows are coming in,â€ he told The Huffington Post. Miranda says heâ€™d love to see more Latinos represented in Hollywood but said it doesnâ€™t take away from the Latino talent that already exists in the industry, particularly the directors whoâ€™ve been recognized by the Academy in recent years.â€œWould I like to see more Latino representation? Would I like to see Hollywood reflect what our country looks like more? Absolutely,â€ Miranda told HuffPost. â€œBut again, we have amazing Latino directors who win tons of Oscars. We have Guillermo del Toro, we have [Alejandro G.] IÃ±arritu, we have [Alfonso] CuarÃ³n. Thereâ€™s no shortage of Latino talent, both in front of and behind the camera.â€As far as the star is concerned, thereâ€™s not a lot that comes out of scrutinizing the list of Oscar nominees each year. â€œI just think to make every year a bellwether.. I donâ€™t know. I donâ€™t know what that does,â€ he added. Still, Miranda thinks the industry should continue â€œto try to make more work and make more opportunities available.â€ The Puerto Rican actor, playwright and composer is currently nominated for an Oscar in the Best Original Song category for â€œHow Far Iâ€™ll Goâ€ in Disneyâ€™s Moana. If he wins, Miranda will be one of the very few artistâ€™s in the industry to have won an Emmy, a Grammy, a Tony and an Oscar â€• not to mention heâ€™s also a Pulitzer Prize winner and a MacArthur fellow. While Miranda feels diversity in the Oscars changes depending on the year, Latino actors have proved to be repeatedly left out of the list of nominees. For example, a Latina has never won the Academy Award for Best Actress, and the last time one was even nominated in the category was in 2004.

headline: Atlanta Falcons Strike Gold Hiring Steve Sarkisian As Offensive Coordinator
short descr: The hire is a stroke of genius.
image_caption(s): Steve Sarkisian is a very gifted play-caller, and will fit in well with the high octane Falcons.
article: Less than 48 hours after their stunning 34-28 overtime defeat to the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LI, the Atlanta Falcons hired Alabamaâ€™s Steve Sarkisian as their new offensive coordinator.Sarkisian served as the Crimson Tideâ€™s OC during the national championship loss to Clemson. He replaces Kyle Shanahan, who on Monday was hired as the new head coach of the San Fransisco 49ers.The Falconsâ€™ move represents a stroke of genius. Sarkisian achieved tremendous success at USC, under Pete Carrollâ€™s regime, and then as the head coach for the University of Washington. He also was quarterbacks coach of the Oakland Raiders in 2004.The 42-year-old Sarkisian isnâ€™t dissimilar from Shanahan. Both are young, swashbuckling play-callers well liked by quarterbacks for their ability to adjust to personnel and willingness to trust signal-callers. One thing that helped Falcons quarterback Matt Ryan earn MVP honors this year while amassing the fifth-best single-season quarterback rating in NFL history was his movement outside the pocket â€• something he rarely did before his two seasons with Shanahan. We can expect Sarkisian â€• who will be Ryanâ€™s fourth OC in 10 years â€• to deploy similar concepts, but with his own twist.After assuming a winless Washington Huskies program in 2009, Sarkisian led UW to five wins during his first season. Then, in his second year, he became bowl eligible with seven wins. In his fourth year, he won nine games, the schoolâ€™s best record in 14 seasons.When USC hired then him as head coach, Sarkisian assembled one of the nationâ€™s elite recruiting classes. Shortly thereafter, however, in October 2015, then-Trojans athletic director Pat Haden fired him after Sarkisian appeared intoxicated during a pep rally speech. Eventually, Sarkisian checked into rehab and sued the school for firing him. The case was settled privately in arbitration.Positivity, culture and brotherhood reign supreme for the Falcons franchise â€• traits that Sarkisian embraces. Heâ€™s a brilliant offensive mind â€• one who appreciates the art of zone-blocking and creativity as a play-caller â€• and a coach who endeared himself to former players despite his issues. Falcons Pro Bowl cornerback Desmond Trufant played for him at UW, and has nothing but good things to say.â€œThatâ€™s my guy,â€ Trufant, 26, told the Atlanta Journal Constitution. â€œI went through a lot with Sark during my college days. I was in his first recruiting class.â€œHe came to my house and recruited. Heâ€™s a dope guy. A very strong guy. A leader. Very passionate about the game. He definitely could get the job done.â€Sarkisian inherits one of the most dominating offenses in NFL history with a quarterback dead-smack in his prime. He also has superstar Julio Jones â€• arguably the greatest wide receiver of his generation, an upper echelon offensive line, and an elite running back tandem DeVonta Freeman and Tevin Coleman.

headline: HUFFPOLLSTER: President Trump's Base Is Sticking With Him
short descr: Republicans give the new president high marks for his first weeks in office. Democrats couldn't disagree more.
image_caption(s): Ariel Edwards-Levy - Senior Reporter and Polling Editor, HuffPost
article: Approval ratings for Donald Trump are split down partisan lines. Support for his travel ban seems to depend on the survey. And the presidentâ€™s Supreme Court nominee gets positive ratings, even though Americans are split on whether the pick should have been his. This is HuffPollster for Tuesday, February 7, 2017.VIEWS OF DONALD TRUMPâ€™S PRESIDENCY ARE DEEPLY POLARIZED - HuffPost Pollsterâ€™s aggregate gives President Trump a 43 percent approval rating, with about 50 percent disapproving. With the exception of Rasmussen, surveys conducted to date this month all show his ratings underwater. Views, however, are deeply polarized -- on average, 86 percent of Republicans approve, compared to just 9 percent of Democrats about 41 percent of independents. (For comparison, Barack Obamaâ€™s early approval ratings were also polarized, but not yet to the same extent â€• in February 2009, he stood at around 89 percent among Democrats, 30 percent with Republicans, and independents just below 60 percent.) [Trump approval chart]Republicans are overwhelmingly happy with Trumpâ€™s actions as president - Emily Guskin: â€œWhile surveys show Trumpâ€™s policies draw mixed reviews from the public overall, almost every one wins majority support from Republicans. What Trump may be reacting to then is that everyone he talks â€• aka loyal supporters â€• seem to love his proposals even though polling shows them with middling supportâ€¦.Take Trumpâ€™s controversial ban on immigration from seven majority-Muslim countries. Polls show support for Trumpâ€™s proposal ranging from small majority support to small majority opposition, suggesting the public is roughly divided on the policy. But even in the poll showing the most negative appraisal, Republicans are overwhelmingly supportiveâ€¦.Broadly speaking, Trumpâ€™s slew of executive orders doesnâ€™t seem to have had a major impact on his overall job approval ratings, though this is little comfort given that he entered office with historically low marks and heavy partisan polarization. Gallup found an average of 43 percent of adults approving of Trump in interviews ending Sunday. Just 8 percent of Democrats and 41 percent of independents approve of the 45th president, but among Republicans 86 percent say he is doing a good job.â€ [WashPost]Are surveys accurately gauging Trumpâ€™s popularity? - Steven Shepard: â€œTraditional phone polls that use live interviewers â€” including some of the most trusted polls in politics and media â€” report limited support for Trump and the controversial executive orders heâ€™s signed. But automated phone and Internet-based surveys tell a different story...Itâ€™s reigniting the campaign debate over whether pollsters are accurately measuring Trumpâ€™s popularity â€” or the breadth of support for his policies. The White House is already seizing on the issue, and forcefully pushing back against the early narrative that the president is suffering from historically bad polling numbersâ€¦.the presidentâ€™s first two weeks in the White House raise questions about whether Trump is better viewed than traditional measures indicate â€” and whether the hard edge of some of his provocative stances and statements will make it difficult to accurately gauge his support right up until his likely reelection bid in 2020.â€ [Politico] Trumpâ€™s sensitivity about his ratings makes polling a potential pressure point - Natalie Jackson: â€œIn an interview with RealClearPolitics, White House press secretary Sean Spicer revealed that Trump consumes polling information with gusto, sometimes telling his advisers about the data before they see it themselves. That means Americans have a direct avenue to getting their voices heard by the president. Answering a phone call or an email to respond to poll questions is more important now than ever â€• it might be the quickest way to have your opinion heard in the Oval Office.â€ [HuffPost]HEREâ€™S WHAT THE LATEST POLLS SAY ABOUT THE TRAVEL BAN - Eight surveys on Donald Trumpâ€™s recent immigration-related executive order show differing levels of public support, but most find a plurality of Americans in opposition. Strikingly, all five of the surveys showing the most support were conducted online or using automated phone calls, while the three finding the least support all used live phone interviewers.Last Fridayâ€™s HuffPollster talked about some of the factors that can lead to variability in issue polling, including question wording â€• such as whether a survey mentions Trumpâ€™s name, or uses the word â€œbanâ€ â€• and mode effects â€• such as social desirability bias, the idea that Americans may be more likely to express an unpopular position anonymously than they are to a live interviewer. But there are also other, more prosaic, possible differences that have more to do with the construction of the surveys themselves. These factors that donâ€™t necessarily lend themselves to a particular outcome, but can certainly have an effect. One poll, for instance, may ask whether someone favors or opposes a proposal, while another asks whether they agree or disagree. One poll may give the option for respondents to say they agree strongly or other somewhat, while another wonâ€™t ask about intensity. And thereâ€™s another difference that could help to explain the noticeable gap between modes. While some pollsters, especially those using online or automated surveys, explicitly give respondents the option to say theyâ€™re not sure about a question, others, especially those using live interviewers, will accept that response only when itâ€™s volunteered.In the case of the travel ban, if the variance between live and online/automated polls were caused by respondentsâ€™ unwillingness to express support non-anonymously, weâ€™d expect higher approval for the ban in polls conducted using the latter method. But with more surveys in, that doesnâ€™t necessarily seem to be the case. With two outlier polls â€• Rasmussen and Gallup â€• excepted, each survey puts approval between 45 percent and 48 percent. Instead, the bigger difference is in the percentage who disapprove, which tends to be lowest among survey that offer respondents an explicit option to say theyâ€™re uncertain. That raises another possibility for the variance: respondents who are inclined to say they arenâ€™t sure, but who, if pushed, come down against the idea.TRUMPâ€™S SCOTUS PICK DRAWS POSITIVE RATINGS - HuffPollster: â€œAmericans have a generally positive first impression of Neil Gorsuch, Donald Trumpâ€™s nominee to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by Justice Antonin Scalia, a new HuffPost/YouGov poll finds. But theyâ€™re split on whether the choice should have been Trumpâ€™s to begin with. Forty percent of Americans approve of the choice of Gorsuch and 28 percent disapprove, with the remaining 32 percent unsure. Among those who approve, 58 percent say itâ€™s mostly because they think Gorsuch would be a good Supreme Court justice, and one-third say itâ€™s because they trust Trump to nominate someone whoâ€™d do a good job. Sixty-six percent of those who disapprove say itâ€™s because they donâ€™t trust Trump to make a good decision, while 28 percent say their disapproval is specifically about Gorsuch himselfâ€¦.Americans are about evenly split on which president should have had the opportunity to choose the next Supreme Court justice, the HuffPost/YouGov survey found, with 41 percent saying Obama should have had the chance to replace Scalia, and 40 percent saying the choice should be Trumpâ€™s.â€ [HuffPost]HUFFPOLLSTER VIA EMAIL! - You can receive this daily update every weekday morning via email! Just click here, enter your email address, and click â€œsign up.â€ Thatâ€™s all there is to it (and you can unsubscribe anytime).TUESDAYâ€™S â€˜OUTLIERSâ€™ - Links to the best of news at the intersection of polling, politics and political data:-Stephen Wolf maps out the 23 Republican-held districts that voted for Hillary Clinton. [Daily Kos (D)]-A new Angus Reid survey finds Americans arenâ€™t ready to give up on NAFTA or the UN. [Angus Reid]-S. Erdem AytaÃ§, Susan Stokes and Eli Rau find that protestors are more likely to vote than most Americans. [WashPost]-Gregory A. Smith reviews Americansâ€™ reluctance to see churches choosing sides in elections. [Pew]-Martha C. White writes that Trumpâ€™s policies are likely to disproportionately hurt his supporters. [NBC]-Stefan Wojcik, Ryan Kennedy and David Lazer give the Socialist Party little chance of winning in the upcoming French election. [WashPost]-The former head of the now defunct Field Poll is named polling director at UC Berkeleyâ€™s Institute of Governmental Studies. [Sacramento Bee]

headline: Republicans Happy To Have Trump Distract The Press As They Move Their Agenda
short descr: GOP lawmakers will take any help they can get.
image_caption(s): Donald Trump's frenetic activity has drawn eyes away from Congress' fumbling on Obamacare.
article: WASHINGTON â€• President Donald Trumpâ€™s first two whirlwind weeks in office have left congressional Republicans gasping over questions of crowd size, â€œalternative facts,â€ even baseless claims about massive voter fraud â€• and that was really just the initial few days. But Trumpâ€™s antics have also handed members a gift: distraction.The often-unhinged tweets, aggressive executive orders and erratic behavior have all provided Republicans some cover as they attempt to repeal a health care law that is becoming more popular.â€œThere is some merit to the argument that would suggest that much of the focus is on what President Trump is doing and not as much on what Congress is doing,â€ House Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) told The Huffington Post. â€œSo it allows for votes to be taken in the House that receive little attention while everybodyâ€™s focused on the bigger agenda items.â€Traditional media score-keeping looks at whether politicians are staying on message. But Trump ripped up that scorecard a year and a half ago. Now, as backlash against the GOP agenda grows, Republicans in Congress are learning how useful it can be to have a lightning rod as president.â€œHeâ€™s eased it somewhat, yeah. I mean, heâ€™s taking the bulk of it,â€ said Rep. Dave Brat (R-Va.), who had just been complaining about Democratic protesters flooding lawmakersâ€™ offices.Republicans know they arenâ€™t going to repeal the Affordable Care Act without criticism.â€œNo matter what we do on Obamacare, itâ€™s going to be a lot of battling because Democrats love the federal government more than anything else,â€ said Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch (R-Utah).Republicans do think, however, that all the different Trump flash points prevent Democrats from targeting just a single item.â€œItâ€™d be easier for detractors to focus on one issue if there werenâ€™t 20 issues happening simultaneously,â€ Rep. Scott Perry (R-Pa.) said.â€œBut I donâ€™t think he sits up at night, â€˜Now theyâ€™re working on that, and I want to, you know, help them shield the blow from the fact that they havenâ€™t decided on and coalesced around one of the three, four, half-a-dozen [Obamacare replacement] plans, so Iâ€™m going to do this,â€™â€ Perry said of Trump. â€œI think heâ€™s just doing what heâ€™s doing.â€ While Perry didnâ€™t buy the idea that Trump was creating all the controversy intentionally, other Republicans werenâ€™t totally sure that the president wasnâ€™t playing some game of 11-dimensional chess.â€œThatâ€™s the question,â€ Rep. Raul Labrador (R-Idaho) said. â€œI think the juryâ€™s still out.â€Labrador laid out the theory that Trump was purposely diverting attention away from Congress. â€œSo then you can do the things that need to be done because heâ€™s distracting on those things,â€ the congressman said.Ultimately, however, he considered Trumpâ€™s unpredictable conduct â€œa wash.â€â€œBecause at some point heâ€™s taking away from his own effectiveness,â€ Labrador said, specifically bringing up Trumpâ€™s decision to attack a â€œso-calledâ€ federal judge rather than make â€œa cogent argument against the judgeâ€™s decision.â€Labrador reported that two Democrats had asked him if Trumpâ€™s bizarre behavior was intentional. â€œBecause they think their leadership is falling for it,â€ he said.Trump certainly has set Democrats â€• and the media â€• a challenge in responding to his every outrage. Before Democrats can meet to discuss their talking points and hold a press conference to decry the latest abuse, Trump is on to the next one. â€œThe president is moving so fast that itâ€™s hard for you guys to keep up sometimes, frankly,â€ Rep. Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) told reporters during a recent GOP retreat.A common sentiment from armchair analysts on Twitter is that everyone is missing the real story when they focus on things like Trumpâ€™s travel ban. (Donâ€™t you get it? Steve Bannon is now on the National Security Council!)But an entirely more plausible explanation is that Trump is most often not trying to distract from his distractions, that there is no master plan behind most of the presidentâ€™s actions and that he is governing from public relations crisis to public relations crisis â€• with a devoted band of followers who think everything he says and does is making America great again.Itâ€™s just that, for Republicans in Congress, the distractions arenâ€™t all good.â€œSometimes helpful, sometimes hurtful,â€ was how Rep. Glenn Grothman (R-Wis.) summed them up.â€œSome of his tweets are an asset, and some, you know, I recommend he not do,â€ Grothman continued.Trumpâ€™s frenetic White House is generating plenty of headlines that the administration canâ€™t be pleased with. (Did Kellyanne Conway really try to flub the â€œBowling Green massacreâ€ or set off the â€œalternative factsâ€ narrative?)But Trump also understands that creating news can be helpful at times. The White Houseâ€™s decision to move up the announcement of its Supreme Court pick seemed motivated by a desire to end coverage on the travel ban.The question is still whether the president has been carrying water for Congress.Thereâ€™s no real evidence that Trump was doing that â€• or, at least, that he was trying to do that. In fact, some Republicans seemed to desire a better messaging relationship with the White House.â€œI just hope in the days ahead we can coordinate a little more closely,â€ Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas) told HuffPost.Itâ€™s the lack of coordination â€• the possibility that Trump could say or do anything â€• that has some Republicans worried.â€œIâ€™m a little concerned about it,â€ Rep. Charlie Dent (R-Pa.) told reporters recently.For Dent, the unpredictable tweets and outbursts really are distracting. â€œIâ€™d rather not be revisiting and rehashing who won the election,â€ he said.When Dent was asked about the prospect of learning administration policy via a Twitter alert, he said some days those Twitter clarifications can be helpful and some days theyâ€™re not.â€œIâ€™ll tell you where it was helpful,â€ he said. â€œA few weeks ago we were talking repeal and delay on Obamacare and then replacing later â€• or hoping to replace later â€• and then the president tweeted out that there should be a repeal and replace simultaneously. That was helpful.â€But Dent would like to see Trump end the erratic behavior. â€œWe have to get onto the serious business of governing,â€ he said. â€œThese other issues are just distractions â€• the crowd size and whatever the other issues are, you know, the voter fraud.â€Or maybe not.Laura Barron-Lopez contributed reporting.
